description: A walking tour exploring how movement of people – both daily and generational – has shaped the built environment of the South Bank. From the arrival of the railways to the housing activism of the 1970s and 80s, the tour will look at how the development of new communities has been instrumental in the creation of London’s most vibrant cultural hub

events.name: A tour through the evolution of the South Bank
events.notes: A walking tour around the South Bank area focusing on the impact of migration on the built environment.

factsheet.heading: Urban Development and Migration
paragraphs: The main focus of this tour is to look at the development of the South Bank area from its industrial beginnings to its establishment as a cultural hub. We will also consider the impact of the ebbs and flows of migration have had on the creation of the built environment of the area we see today.

factsheet.heading: Golden Key Academy
paragraphs: This tour is led by a participant of Open City’s Golden Key Academy – a course training up insightful and engaging guides dedicated to explaining London and bringing its many stories to life. It is part of a wider collection of tours created by Golden Key Academy guides for the Open House Festival celebrating their conclusion of the eight month course. Further information on the Golden Key Academy can be found here https://open-city.org.uk/golden-key-academy

factsheet.heading: About your guide
paragraphs: Having worked in London for 20 years, Ben LeGrys recently graduated from Kingston School of Art with a MA in Museum & Gallery Studies and has an interest in the impact and recognition of migrant labour on the built environment of London

location.address: Emma Cons Gardens (corner of The Cut and Waterloo Road), SE1 8TQ
travel_info: Additional travel info: The tour will end in Jubilee Gardens.

name: Ebbs and flows:  a tour through the evolution of the South Bank
